block.p: Warnaco Warns on Profit And Investors Punish Stock Warnaco, the maker of intimate apparel, said that it would miss earnings estimates by a wide margin, the third time it has missed projections in the last year. The company said operating earnings for the 2000 fiscal year would be 26 to 36 cents a share, almost $1.50 less than Wall Street analysts had projected.
Irate investors sent Warnaco shares down $1.8125, to $4.9375. They are now down nearly 60 percent this year, and off 89 percent from their high of $44 in 1998. [Page C2.]

Movies Added to Music Dispute Expanding their legal attack on the exchange of copyrighted works on the Internet, the motion picture and music industries sued to shut down Scour.com, a venture backed by Michael Ovitz that the industries contend permits not just free trading of copyrighted music files but of movies. In invoking the film issue, the lawsuit adds a wrinkle to a dispute that has focused largely on music. [C2.]

Merger of Railroads Is Called Off The largest rail merger in North American history was formally scrapped as the railroads involved -- Burlington Northern Santa Fe and the Canadian National Railway -- complained about regulatory interference and shippers remained convinced that they have not seen the end of the consolidation that has so far left just a handful of major freight railroads to serve the United States and Canada. [C2.]

Mechanics Cause Trouble for United United Airlines, already reeling from the refusal of many of its 10,000 pilots to work overtime, is now facing similar difficulties from its 15,000 mechanics, whose contract with the airline expired on July 12. [C6.]

Bertelsmann Plans to Buy CDNow Bertelsmann, the German media conglomerate, will buy CDNow, the struggling online music retailer, for $117 million in cash. The deal will give Bertelsmann a recognized brand in online music sales as it attempts to expand its electronic commerce business. [C4.]

A Guiding Hand for Mexico's Leader Luis Ernesto Derbez, a World Bank manager who had served in Africa, Asia and Central America, has become a leading adviser to Vicente Fox, the president-elect of Mexico. [C3.]

Eminent Copywriter Joins Artustry Helayne Spivak, a well-known copywriter who has worked at several large agencies like Ammirati Puris Lintas, J. Walter Thompson and Young & Rubicam Advertising, is joining David Sklaver and his partners at the Artustry Partnership in New York, a shop that provides creative and strategic services to advertisers seeking to work outside the realm of traditional agencies. Ms. Spivak, 48, will be a creative partner, joining the three executives who founded the shop in fall 1998. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. [C6.]

Housing Construction Declines 3% Housing construction fell 3 percent in June, to its lowest level in more than two years, responding to a string of interest rate increases, government figures showed. [C8.]

Profit Doubles at America Online America Online posted a 115 percent gain in fourth-quarter profit, slightly beating the expectations of analysts, who said the results were solid but contained few surprises. [C4.]
Sun Microsystems reported profit that exceeded forecasts, lifted by continued strong sales of servers that help power the Internet. [C2.]

Earnings Fall at Mattel and Hasbro Mattel and Hasbro, two of the largest toymakers, said that second-quarter profits fell as sales slowed and an increase in the value of the dollar hurt earnings from overseas. [C6.]

Gillette Posts 2.1% Gain in Profit Gillette said that its second-quarter earnings rose 2.1 percent, on increased sales of its Mach 3 blades. Its shares fell after the company said it would retain its Braun unit. [C6.]
